docs.lead_paragraph: More than 2,000 workers from 1199, the health-care workers' union, filled City Hall Park yesterday to rally in favor of a bill that would require companies that have contracts with the city to pay workers at least $8.10 an hour with health benefits, or $9.60 an hour without benefits. The City Council speaker, Gifford Miller, and 1199's president, Dennis Rivera, above, spoke at the rally. Several City Council members support the legislation, which would raise pay for 50,000 home health-care attendants who now earn less than $7.70 an hour. The bill would raise their pay to at least $10 an hour by 2006. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Union Rally

byline.original: By Steven Greenhouse (NYT) (Compiled by Anthony Ramirez)

docs.lead_paragraph: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. Now Playing ''ALL ABOUT THE BENJAMINS,'' starring Ice Cube and Mike Epps. Directed by Kevin Bray (R, 99 minutes). In this fast, violent caper comedy, Ice Cube and Mr. Epps reprise the hip-hop-era, Martin-and-Lewis routing they inaugurated in ''Next Friday.'' There are some funny bits and a few stylish action sequences as the pair, playing a roughneck bounty hunter (Ice Cube) and a motormouth petty con man (Mr. Epps), chase after stolen diamonds, a winning lottery ticket and an international cast of bad guys. But the light comic tone is marred by gruesome, sadistic violence, and the rabid materialism suggested by the title (which refers to $100 bills) has an ugly, cynical edge (A. O. Scott).

docs.lead_paragraph: Here in New Jersey's capital, governors and lawmakers don't even suggest raising taxes, no matter how dire the state's finances, as Gov. James E. McGreevey's new budget plan makes clear. But out in the towns and counties, where the better part of a voter's taxes are paid, local officials are projecting property tax increases on a scale not seen in 10 years. New Jersey already has the highest per-capita property taxes in the nation. And in the spring ritual of presenting next year's budgets, including the school budgets that will go before voters on April 16, almost all towns are proposing increases in tax rates; a few are expected to raise the average tax bill by nearly $1,000.

headline.main: A Word From Trenton Translates Into 3: Higher Local Taxes

docs.abstract: New Jersey municipalities are preparing for big property tax hikes; state already has highest property taxes per capita in nation, but with state freeze on aid to local governments announced by Gov James McGreevey, towns have no other option but turning to homeowners; graph tracks property taxes since 1982 (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The State Assembly is preparing to concede one of several points on a stalled bill that would require insurers to pay for contraception and cancer screening for women, a co-sponsor of the bill said today. A vote on a new version of the bill could come as early as Monday. Most of the hot debate over the bill, the Women's Health and Wellness Act, has focused on whether religious institutions should be forced to contribute to health care plans that cover contraception if it violates their beliefs to do so.

headline.main: Assembly Concession May Move Stalled Women's Health Bill

docs.abstract: New York State Assembly may concede point on stalled bill that would require insurers to pay for contraception and cancer screening for women; debate is over Senate-approved provision that would let religious employers opt out of covering contraception, but only if most of employees and most of clients share religious objection to contraception; Assemblywomen Deborah Glick, lead sponsor of bill, opposes religious exemption but says she is committed to getting law enacted this session (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Two podiatrists have pleaded guilty in a $30 million Medicare fraud scheme that prosecutors said spanned eight years. Yesterday, a federal judge in Manhattan accepted the guilty pleas of the two podiatrists, Drs. Michael Brumer and Lawrence Klein, who admitted to conspiring to and committing health fraud and conspiring to take kickbacks, said Marvin Smilon, a spokesman for the United States attorney's office.

headline.main: 2 Podiatrists Plead Guilty in $30 Million Scheme to Defraud Medicare and Take Kickbacks

docs.abstract: Drs Michael Brumer and Lawrence Klein plead guilty to conspiracy and health care fraud in scheme that victimized poor, elderly and minority New York City residents, private health insurance companies and Medicare; billed for costly services like surgery and x-rays, when only routine care was provided (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki is starring in a major new state advertising campaign, this time as he runs for re-election, and his Democratic opponents today accused him of using public money to further his political fortunes. The television ads, which began running a few days ago, promote Family Health Plus, a new state program to provide health insurance to low-income adults who are not poor enough to qualify for Medicaid. John Signor, a Health Department spokesman, said he could not provide a dollar figure for the advertising effort, or say how long it would last, but the commercials have appeared with a frequency comparable to those of other state ad campaigns that have cost as much as $1 million a month.

headline.main: Pataki's Presence in State Ads Is Campaign Tool, Critics Say

The bill, Mr. Pataki asserted, was part of his effort to improve health care in New York. -- from an interview with Gov. George E. docs.lead_paragraph: When George E. Pataki first ran for governor of New York, as a junior Republican state senator taking on Mario M. Cuomo in 1994, he campaigned on a platform that was crisp and unmistakably conservative. Mr. Pataki pledged to reimpose the death penalty. He told voters he would slash spending, cut taxes and reduce the welfare rolls. And he promised to shrink a government that, he said, had bloated under 20 years of Democratic rule. But the candidate who is now seeking a third term as governor is in many ways different from that little-known state senator from Peekskill who confounded Mr. Cuomo eight years ago. Nowhere was that more obvious than at his Manhattan campaign headquarters the other day, where he accepted the endorsement of a group of black ministers, most of them Democrats.

headline.main: The Postpartisan Governor; Defying a Democratic Tide, Pataki Seeks a Third Term

docs.abstract: George Pataki is in remarkably strong position as he campaigns for third term as governor of New York; Pataki, a Republican who is defying tide of increasingly Democratic state, says his political strength is testimony to his success as governor; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Billy M. Mann is worried about the future. At 80 years old, Mr. Mann, a retired Arthur Andersen partner, sees trouble ahead for his pension of $42,000 a year and other benefits owed to him from 36 years at Andersen. He says he is not one for poor-mouthing, and he admits that ''we're not in danger of going hungry or anything like that.'' But if Arthur Andersen files for bankruptcy or takes other actions that would cut off those benefits, Mr. Mann said, he and his wife, Jean, will have to make some changes.

headline.main: Andersen's Retired Partners Fear Benefits May Slip Away

docs.abstract: Retired Arthur Andersen partners file lawsuit to protect their pensions and other benefits if firm files for bankruptcy or takes other action that might cut benefits off; firm's partner-owners do not have typical pension with backstop of Pension Benefits Guaranty Corp, which makes payments when companies go bankrupt, and they do not have 401(k) plans; are encouraged to invest for their own retirement, partly through Keogh accounts, and firm provides partners with stipend, now $3,500 a month, as safety net should their investments go awry; retirees who are not partners have more financial backing for their retirement benefits; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A new process now undergoing final testing may rid donated blood of virtually all viruses and bacteria, bringing a new level of safety to blood transfusions. Experts say the process, which uses chemicals that gum up the genetic material of germs, could eliminate the rare cases of AIDS transmission through transfusions that are not already caught by testing blood and screening donors.

headline.main: Technique May Improve Safety of Donated Blood

docs.abstract: Article on pathogen inactivation, technique undergoing final testing at Cerus Corp in Concord, Calif, that may eliminate virtually all viruses and bacteria from donated blood; photo (M)
